All patients should\nbe given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).\nModule 2 Recommended Practices \n2.1 Glucose management\n2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately\n2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first\nrandom glucose value is &gt; 11 mmol/L\n2.2 Body temperature\n2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs\nevery 4 hours for first 48 hours\nFor temperature &gt; 37.5 C:\n• initiate temperature-reducing measures\n• investigate potential infection\n• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required\n2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should\nbe given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention\nassessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\n2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\n2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:\n• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-\nrisk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and\ninitiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)\nas soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,\nfollowed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each\npatient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends\nthat:\no such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor\nstroke clinicc\no where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic\npose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur\nat an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be\ngiven to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke\nprevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of\naccreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure\nequitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of\nthe location of initial presentation\no where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from\nsymptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a\nspecialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient\nclinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial\npresentation\n• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without\nhigh-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of\nantiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as\npossible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,\nfollowed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention\nservicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1\nmonth of symptom onset\n2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or\ncrescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech\ndifficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission\nto hospital\n2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on\nan antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on\nantiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain\nimaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:\n• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–\n325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of\n81 mg/day\n• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day\n• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with\nASA 160 mg first)\n2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as\nfor patients who fail swallowing screening\n2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,\nNational Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\naSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high\nrisk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery\natherosclerosis with &gt; 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.\nbPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging\ncA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and\nvascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.\ndFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.\neMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or\narm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\nModule 2 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as\npossible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED\n• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA\nAbbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department.', 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' ', 'error_prompt': "'' on line 3 does not conform to the format."} |

| **user_role_prompt** | You're a team leader. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |
| **task_prompt** | Module 2: Early Treatment This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). Module 2 Recommended Practices  2.1 Glucose management 2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately 2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first random glucose value is &gt; 11 mmol/L 2.2 Body temperature 2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours For temperature &gt; 37.5 C: • initiate temperature-reducing measures • investigate potential infection • initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required 2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed: • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high- risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset, followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends that: o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinicc o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of the location of initial presentation o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial presentation • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation, followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset 2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital 2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage: • ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81– 325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of 81 mg/day • clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day • extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with ASA 160 mg first) 2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as for patients who fail swallowing screening 2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery atherosclerosis with &gt; 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event. bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests. dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus. eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 2 Implementation Considerations General considerations • Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED • Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department. |
| **with_task_specify** | False |
| **memory** | current memory not loaded |
| **model_type** | ModelType.GPT_4o1 |

50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.\nbPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging\ncA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and\nvascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.\ndFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.\neMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or\narm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\nModule 2 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as\npossible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED\n• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA\nAbbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; [2025-29-04 15:39:51 INFO] Team leader: **[Start Chat]**

[You're a process design reviewer. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include give suggestion to the process.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 2: Early Treatment
This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The
majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital
and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or
comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should
be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).
Module 2 Recommended Practices 
2.1 Glucose management
2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately
2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first
random glucose value is > 11 mmol/L
2.2 Body temperature
2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs
every 4 hours for first 48 hours
For temperature > 37.5 C:
• initiate temperature-reducing measures
• investigate potential infection
• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required
2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should
be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention
assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-
risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and
initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)
as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,
followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each
patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends
that:
o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor
stroke clinicc
o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic
pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur
at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be
given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke
prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of
accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure
equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of
the location of initial presentation
o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from
symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a
specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient
clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial
presentation
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without
high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of
antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as
possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,
followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention
servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1
month of symptom onset
2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or
crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech
difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission
to hospital
2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on
an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on
antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain
imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:
• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–
325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of
81 mg/day
• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day
• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with
ASA 160 mg first)
2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as
for patients who fail swallowing screening
2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,
National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.
aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high
risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery
atherosclerosis with > 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.
bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging
cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and
vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.
dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.
eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or
arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.
Module 2 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as
possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED
• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA
Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

Your task is to add calls to a Format Checking API to a piece of process text. You can call the API by writing '<API>check(text)</API>' where 'text' is the process text you need to check for formatting. Here are an example of API calls:
Input: 
Please check the format of the process text:
<process>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch id='branch1'>
      <activity role='user' action='Alipay payment' objects='Commodity' id='activity3'/> 
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch2'>
      <activity role='user' action='Wechat payment' objects='Commodity' id='activity3'/> 
  </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
</process>
Output: 
Please check the format of the process text:
<API>check(
<process>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch id='branch1'>
      <activity role='user' action='Alipay payment' objects='Commodity' id='activity3'/> 
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch2'>
      <activity role='user' action='Wechat payment' objects='Commodity' id='activity3'/> 
  </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
</process>)</API>
Now, my input is: 
Please check the format of the process text:
<process>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate early treatment protocol for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke' objects='suspected TIA/minor stroke patient' id='activity1'/>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Assess blood glucose' objects='patient, glucometer' id='activity2'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch condition='Hypoglycemia detected' id='branch1'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Correct hypoglycemia immediately' objects='patient, glucose' id='activity3'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='First random glucose > 11 mmol/L' id='branch2'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Repeat blood glucose measurement' objects='patient, glucometer' id='activity4'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='Glucose normal and ≤ 11 mmol/L' id='branch3'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue standard monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity5'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate body temperature as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours' objects='patient, thermometer' id='activity6'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
    <branch condition='Temperature > 37.5°C' id='branch4'>
      <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway1'>
        <branch id='branch5'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate temperature-reducing measures' objects='patient, cooling devices/medications' id='activity7'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch6'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order laboratory tests for infection' objects='patient, laboratory tests' id='activity8'/>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Review laboratory results and determine infection source' objects='patient, laboratory results' id='activity9'/>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required' objects='patient, medications' id='activity10'/>
        </branch>
      </parallelGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='Temperature ≤ 37.5°C' id='branch8'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue routine temperature monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity11'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway2'>
    <branch id='branch9'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)' objects='patient' id='activity12'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch10'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Assess for OHTAC recommendations and risk features' objects='patient, clinical criteria' id='activity13'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway3'>
        <branch condition='TIA with high-risk features or minor stroke' id='branch11'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order brain CT scan' objects='patient, CT scanner' id='activity14'/>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antiplatelet therapy if not contraindicated' objects='patient, antiplatelet medication' id='activity15'/>
          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway4'>

              <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate in ED for possible hospital admission' objects='patient' id='activity16'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='No fluctuating/crescendo symptoms' id='branch13'>
              <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway5'>
                <branch condition='Immediate access to specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic' id='branch14'>
                  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer patient to specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation' objects='patient, referral documentation' id='activity17'/>
                </branch>
                <branch condition='Delay to specialized clinic poses risk' id='branch15'>
                  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Conduct evaluation in ED and consider inpatient evaluation and management for stroke prevention' objects='patient, ED resources' id='activity18'/>
                </branch>
                <branch condition='Medical attention sought after 48 hours from symptom onset' id='branch16'>
                  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer for evaluation at specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention services within 24 hours of initial presentation' objects='patient, referral documentation' id='activity19'/>
                </branch>
              </exclusiveGateway>
            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='TIA without high-risk features' id='branch17'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order brain CT scan' objects='patient, CT scanner' id='activity20'/>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antiplatelet therapy if not contraindicated' objects='patient, antiplatelet medication' id='activity21'/>
          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway6'>
            <branch condition='Fluctuating/crescendo hemibody motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty' id='branch18'>
              <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate in ED for possible hospital admission' objects='patient' id='activity22'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='No fluctuating/crescendo symptoms' id='branch19'>
              <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer to outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention services for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset' objects='patient, referral documentation' id='activity23'/>
            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway7'>
        <branch condition='Patient not on antiplatelet agent at presentation and brain imaging excludes intracranial hemorrhage' id='branch20'>
          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway8'>
            <branch condition='ASA selected' id='branch21'>
              <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Administer ASA 160 mg loading dose, then enteric coated ASA (81–325 mg) daily (maintenance 81 mg/day for most)' objects='patient, ASA' id='activity24'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='Clopidogrel selected' id='branch22'>
              <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Administer clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, then 75 mg/day' objects='patient, clopidogrel' id='activity25'/>

            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient already on antiplatelet agent or contraindicated' id='branch24'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue or adjust antiplatelet therapy as clinically indicated' objects='patient, medication list' id='activity27'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway9'>
        <branch condition='Patient fails swallowing screening' id='branch25'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Offer rectal or gastric ASA as necessary' objects='patient, rectal/gastric ASA' id='activity28'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient passes swallowing screening' id='branch26'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Administer oral antiplatelet therapy as indicated' objects='patient, oral medication' id='activity29'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
  </parallelGateway>
</process>

[2025-29-04 15:40:13 INFO] Process design reviewer: **Process design reviewer<->Team leader on : AddAPI, turn 0**

[You're a team leader. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 2: Early Treatment
This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The
majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital
and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or
comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should
be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).
Module 2 Recommended Practices 
2.1 Glucose management
2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately
2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first
random glucose value is > 11 mmol/L
2.2 Body temperature
2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs
every 4 hours for first 48 hours
For temperature > 37.5 C:
• initiate temperature-reducing measures
• investigate potential infection
• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required
2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should
be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention
assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-
risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and
initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)
as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,
followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each
patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends
that:
o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor
stroke clinicc
o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic
pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur
at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be
given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke
prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of
accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure
equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of
the location of initial presentation
o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from
symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a
specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient
clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial
presentation
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without
high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of
antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as
possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,
followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention
servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1
month of symptom onset
2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or
crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech
difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission
to hospital
2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on
an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on
antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain
imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:
• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–
325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of
81 mg/day
• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day
• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with
ASA 160 mg first)
2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as
for patients who fail swallowing screening
2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,
National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.
aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high
risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery
atherosclerosis with > 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.
bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging
cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and
vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.
dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.
eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or
arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.
Module 2 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as
possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED
• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA
Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

Please check the format of the process text:
